title: Monday, 21st March, 2016

11:15 am
BE

While we see 12% upside just on a SOP
valuation using Hotels / Starbucks multiples, we note that recent like-forlike
softness might limit the comparability with pure-play peers.

BE

Sum-of-the-parts leaves 12% upside. We arrive at a fair value of
4,399p per share using hotel multiples to value Premier Inn (Accor,
Hyatt, Wyndham, avg. 8.4x CY17e EV / EBITDA) and Starbucks
multiples to value Costa coffee (14.5x).

BE

14.5 times EV / EBITDA for Costa?!

11:16 am
BE

De-merger precedents are supportive. The Accor Edenred (2010)
and Autogrill World Duty Free (2013) demergers, in our view, helped
crystallise hidden value by separating entities with diverging growth
profiles and capital requirements. Premier Inn and Costa have very
strong similarities in their rollout-driven growth profiles (c. 2-3% LFL
growth potential complemented by 6-9% network growth). However
they boast different returns (13.5% and 46.3% ROCE, respectively) and
capex profiles (4.7x and 1.5x depreciation, respectively).

BE

Short term upside clouded by like-for-like underperformance. For
fiscal Q416, Costa reported like-for-like growth of +0.5%, and
management is guiding at 2-3% for fiscal FY17. In contrast, Starbucks
global comparable store sales increased by +8% in the overlapping fiscal
Q116 (of which +9% in the Americas), with management guiding at FY
same store growth “somewhat above mid-single digit”. This might limit
investors’ willingness to value Costa on the same multiple as its only
listed pure play peer.

BE

Next possible catalysts. Whitbread “does not comment on market
rumor or speculation.” The complete FY results presentation on 26th
April will include more details on the rollout targets across Premier Inn
and Costa. We expect the AGM to be held in June. Management do not
expect to hold a formal investor day before November 2016

BE

The fact is that Sainsbury's deal looks cheap and tricksy. It'd be equally cheap and tricksy for a peer.

BE

And we know that Sainsbury has a natural ceiling to which it can bid, while avoiding it becoming a class one transaction requiring a shareholder vote.

BE

It I were Andy Clarke at Asda, I'd stick in a "potential counter offer" statement just to mess with Sainsbury. What's the downside here?

11:24 am

11:25 am
BE

Yeah -- but could just do a Steinhoff. Bit of mulling, make them sweat in Holborn for a bit, then say .... "nah, it's rubbish."

BE

Anyway, here's SocGen.

BE

Update On Friday evening Steinhoff announced that it will not make a formal offer for Home Retail Group (HRG), preferring to focus on its offer for Darty in France. Against this backdrop, Sainsbury appears well-placed to acquire HRG. Indeed, on Friday evening Sainsbury confirmed its offer at 170.5p on that day’s closing price: 0.321 x 273.2p+ 55p in cash + 27.8p special dividend mainly linked to disposal of Homebase. This implies a potential split of 51% in Sainsbury shares and 49% cash. Sainsbury apparently now sees scope for a higher level of EBITDA synergies, i.e., ‘not less than £160m’, up from ‘not less than £120m’. We think this 1/3 rise in targeted synergies can mainly be explained by the need to be more aggressive to convince HRG's board and
investors, while Steinhoff's informal offer had the advantage of being 100% cash (175p). HRG shareholders would hold 12% of Sainsbury’s enlarged ordinary share capital base. We estimate the deal would be 1% earnings enhancing with zero synergies in year 3 but 20% accretive assuming £160m of synergies.

11:26 am
BE

SG view It is clear that the 'online' revolution and rapid changes in customer behaviour will force traditional players to adapt their business models and accelerate their multi-channel strategies.
Like the other UK food retailers, Sainsbury is no exception, but at this stage we have some
concerns on the potential HRG deal, partly explaining our recent downgrade from Buy to Hold (see Increased risk profile): 1) Risky timing as UK food retailing has not yet stabilized; 2) Loss of the pure player status; 3) Uncertain synergies. Conference call at 9.00 am UK time today.
How we value the stock Our 260p TP is based on a peer comparison (255p, a 35% 2016-17e P/E discount to the European food retailing sector) and a DCF (265p, WACC 8.6%, growth to perpetuity 1.5%, normalised EBIT margin 3.0% as of 2022-23e).
Events, catalysts & risks to price target, rating & recommendation FY results 4 May.
Risks: downside – higher price investment than the £150m initially planned for 2015-16; higher one-offs costs related to HRG bid (£140m targeted by management); a higher bid for HRG would undermine the financial rationale, which in turn would raise investor concerns about the group's future; upside – higher HRG synergies than the ‘at least £160m’ targeted by the group.

BE

Here's what confuses me here, regarding the possibility of a counter.........

BE

Either Clarke doesn't want Argos because he thinks Asda can be rescued another way he's not mentioned, and fair enough. Or he does want Argos but isn't getting the backing from the big bosses in Bentonville, in which case he should probably resign.

11:28 am
BE

Jefferies incoming.

BE

JS has secured Argos on the original terms outlined a few weeks ago. This is a
helpful dynamic for the group as it provides a potentially meaningful source of
new earnings (with synergy targets now upped to £160m) at a time when the
outlook for the core business remains uncertain. Still, we lack the elements to
conclude that this delivers material enough upside for a more active stance.
Sainsbury wins. Steinhoff confirmed on Friday it would make no offer for HRG. JS firmed
up its bid for HRG. Each HRG share will be exchanged for 0.321 SBRY stock and 55p cash
(another 27.8p will come from HRG distributions).
Gross impact more positive than previously expected. JS upped its synergy target
from £120m to £160m by the third full year of integration. This largely reflects a £30m
increase in fixed cost and buying savings. The £140m of incremental capex remains in line
with previous indications, but exceptional costs have reduced £10m to £130m. Targeted
accretion is still at double-digit level at full integration, and returns in the low to mid-teens
region.

BE

We need more information to firm up the impact... Our estimates (still not reflected
in our published SBRY model) presume net earnings accretion of MSD% by 19/20, assuming
Argos sales of £4.15bn and EBIT margin of 3.5% by that stage. Our shortfall likely reflects
a less optimistic view both on Argos sales and margin, relative to those underpinning
Sainsbury's ambitions. We will seek more details on the latter before incorporating Argos
in our model.
...but believe this is a net positive for JS. We believe that the deliverability of savings
is strongly underpinned by the ability to wind down lease structures at Argos. We are
less certain about the extent to which the Argos trials in Sainsbury stores can provide
more confidence on sales retention and/or growth. We will also need to audit how Argos'
commercial proposition currently stacks up in what is a rapidly changing context. Finally JS
has confirmed its previous view on expectations, with the group stating back in September
2015 that it expected 15/16 PBT moderately ahead of £548m consensus (this has now
increased to £573m vs. JEFe £563m).

11:31 am
BE

Implications
Key updates relative to the 2nd February announcement:
1) Sainsbury now expects EBITDA synergies of not less than £160mn in the
third full year after completion, an increase from the previous estimate of
not less than £120mn.
2) Sainsbury’s and the trustee of the HRG pension scheme have reached
agreements with regards to the future funding of the HRG pension
scheme, if the deal completes. Under this agreement, Argos would pay an
additional £40mn p.a. in deficit contributions and a £50mn lump sum
following completion.
While we do not take a view on the likelihood of the proposed deal taking
place, for illustrative purposes we have undertaken a scenario analysis that
suggests the deal would be 18-30% EPS accretive in year 3 at an achieved
synergy range of £120-160mn and depending on whether additional
pension contributions are considered earnings dilutive.

11:33 am
PM

BE

Actually, that's entirely unfair. This is Adam Cochrane, with one of UBS's epic "evidence lab" pieces.

BE

We take a more cautious view on the UK general retail sector over the next 12 months as short-term uncertainty over Brexit and wage inflation is compounded by FX issues and the increasing impact of Amazon on the sector. The most important transactional currency for UK general retail is the GBP/USD and, with a range of 1.55 to 1.25, we calculate that theoretical sector earnings impact for 2017 could be between +20% and -40% from current spot rates before any mitigation or price increase. History suggests a significant degree of mitigation is possible but, in our view, given the significantly net importing nature of UK retail, the uncertainty will weigh on valuation. After four years of outperformance we believe that the above-average sector valuation may normalise as earnings growth slows in the face of the above headwinds. 

11:34 am
BE

Our survey of 2000 UK consumers completed in January 2016 indicates that there is c.3-5% more caution around spending than a year ago, with only the lower to middle income brackets feeling slightly more confident. In terms of category spend discount retail still comes out the winner, with c.20% expecting to spend more in this category compared to c.10% in homewares and 8% in clothing. One of the clearest conclusions is the increasing dominance of Amazon across clothing, homewares and even DIY in terms of both historical spending and future spending intentions. 

BE

We think Amazon growth has accelerated in 2015 after relatively lacklustre years in 2013 and 2014. At the reported level Amazon sales grew 15% in 2015 but if we gross this up to GMV it would be significantly higher. As the marketplace offer broadened and Prime membership increased we estimate that Amazon may have taken up to 25% of the total growth in UK non-food retail sales in 2015.

BE

So, Halfords goes down to sell.

We upgrade Sports Direct to BUY from Hold and our TP to 510p from 470p. Following a 48% fall in the shares in the past six months we do not see the lack of acquisitions as an obstacle to earnings growth nor does the rating require earnings-enhancing M&A. The strong balance sheet and c£200m of free cash flow p.a. could be deployed in other ways. FCF could buy back more than 10% of the company per year which could drive 43% EPS upside by 2019.

11:37 am

Using 100% of free cash flow to fund buybacks enhances EPS by 43% in three years and 117% by 2021. With 50% we see 18% enhancement by 2018 and 37% by 2021

BE

On the assumption that SPD spends 100% of its FCF on buybacks the company maintains c£100m net cash. On the basis of 50% we forecast £500m net cash by 2018.

BE

In 2007 and 2008 SPD spent £1.1bn in buying back shares as recession took the share price from 276p to a low of 32p at the end of 2008.

PM

Pershing Square Letter to Allergan’s Board:
July 16th, 2014

PM

In my 21-year history as a governance investor, I cannot think of another example in our portfolio where a board has behaved as poorly as you have in your response to the Valeant merger proposal. Your scorched earth response to Valeant is beyond the pale. You have accused Valeant of fraudulent accounting and of falsifying its reported growth rates and business performance, and you have done so without factual evidence to prove these assertions. If one spreads false and misleading information for the purpose of driving down Valeant’s stock price, that is market manipulation, plain and simple. That a board of a $50 billion market cap company would engage in such behavior as a defensive tactic is extraordinary and incredibly inappropriate.

BE

As VRX’s troubles mounted, the market clearly shifted from valuing the business on an EPS
basis to EV/EBITDA one. While default on the debt seems remote, there’s enough
uncertainty that equity investors focused increasingly on VRX’s ability meet its debt
obligations and what would be left for shareholders. Less than 25% of VRX’s enterprise
value lies with equity currently. As the market gains comfort with VRX, incremental value
all flows to equity holders which implies meaningful leverage in the share price. Magnifying
this will be restoration of management’s credibility with investors, which VRX itself
acknowledges has been damaged by recent events. We believe recent additions to the
board of directors, including Fred Eshelman, an executive we’ve known from a long time in
covering PPD, is a good first step in this regard, though has been overshadowed by events.
We’re basing our price target on EV/sales because given the uncertainty in the situation, it
provides easiest comparison across the industry since VRX varies from the peer group
based on tax (though less so today), R&D and even SG&A spend. Given the fluidity of the
situation, we appreciate that our $34 price target (3.7x our revenue estimate from 2Q16-
1Q17) is somewhat arbitrary. Our prior $135 price target was based on 10.2x our FY16 EPS
estimate of $13.25. We’ve obviously seen expectations for earnings come down
meaningfully, as well as a change in tax reporting, which we believe supports our
conversion to EV/sales as our preferred valuation methodology for the time being.
We’re inclined to think shares will be considerably higher in 12 months, though we can’t
completely dismiss that shares could be lower. MYL trades at 2.7x EV/sales and GSK at
3.2x. Even 3x would imply just $12/share for VRX. That’s not necessarily a fair comparison
since a brand portfolio should command a premium to MYL, which remains largely a
generic manufacturer, but if VRX isn’t able to resolve the challenges at play, we’d argue
such a discount to brand peers isn’t completely unreasonable. For all its challenges, VRX
doesn’t face generic competition as GSK whose respiratory franchise potentially faces
competition as soon as mid-2017.
If VRX is able to restore confidence, though, and demonstrate it can drive EBITDA back to a
$7 billion EBITDA run-rate by 2018, then we would expect shares trade based on that
valuation metric which is where the spec pharma group now seems to trade. An 8x
EV/EBITDA multiple which would imply shares above $75 over the next 12 months;
alternatively this would represent 5x EV/sales.

BE

11:52 am
Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 7.98, up 0.37 (+4.86%), High: 8.19, Low: 6.80, Volume: 9.78m
BE

Can't quite understand why they were holding said towel in the first place.

BE

Main issues

Debt. Over the next c.20 months, in the absence of debt restructuring, GKP is required to repay principal of $575m and coupons of $89.4m to its bondholders ($325m convertible bonds, coupon 6.25%, due October '17; $250m senior notes, coupon 13%, due April '17). Against this the company has current cash of $51m (mid March) and anticipated incoming cashflow for oil produced and repayments of c.$15m/month.

Shaikan field. With gross 2P reserves of 639 mmbbls Shaikan is a large field, and the initial performance has been good. GKP (WI 58%, op.) has been hampered by its restricted financial resources, which have allowed only c.40 kbopd capacity to be developed, well short of the full field potential. The asset scale and quality are positive for GKP, but that also makes it attractive to the lenders, and we think that has been enhanced with the resolution of holdings and adjustments to the licence terms.

In the near term a lack of investment looks likely to lead to potentially significant production declines. Currently, the committed budget is only $6m, but GKP has put forward plans to maintain 40 kbopd production (capex $71m) or to increase it to 55 kbopd (capex $88m). Unfortunately it is hard to see how the company can finance this given the debt obligations, G&A outgoings, and limited anticipated incoming cashflow.

11:53 am
BE

Valuation and rating

Gulf Keystone is in a very difficult position with limited time to find a solution to the overhanging debt issues. In our view the risks associated with the company now merit an assumption of NPV20 (previously 15%) valuation. Based on the various licence term amendments and inclusion of a number of financial adjustments, our NPV20 central value declines to 5p/share (from 15p). Yet even that assumes asset value which is currently beyond the company's financial capacity to realise. On that basis we set our TP at 4p/share (from 15p) and reduce our rating to SELL from Hold.

Our TP approaches the remaining potential equity value in our view c.2p/share or 5% of projected EV, that may remain if the debt obligations cannot be met.

BE

While it's not our place to give investment advice, that 4p target looks pretty punchy to me.

11:54 am
BE

On Tungsten, which was requested earlier ..........

BE

The statement speaks for itself, I guess.

BE

Response to Press Speculation

11:55 am
BE

(Hm.)

BE

(Late Sunday evening Kleinman speculation. Hm.)

BE

The Board of Tungsten Corporation Plc ("Tungsten") notes the recent media speculation in relation to Edmund Truell ("Mr. Truell") and his purported offer for Tungsten assets and wishes to provide a clarificatory response.

Mr. Truell ceased to be CEO in July 2015 following a very difficult period for the company and we have today announced his resignation from the board. Since July 2015, Mr. Truell has made a number of suggestions in relation to combining operating businesses owned by Tungsten with other businesses in which he has an interest, including Tantalum, a vehicle telematics business.

The Board received an outline of a new transaction structure from Mr. Truell on Saturday 19th March 2016 which, like its predecessors, did not involve an offer for Tungsten's shares but instead suggested that Tungsten's network business and the cash it expects to receive from the proposed sale of its bank be combined with certain assets in which he has a majority interest in, including Tantalum.

The resulting effect of this conceived combination would be that Tungsten's primary asset would be a minority stake in an enlarged group of disparate, illiquid assets controlled by Mr. Truell and Tungsten itself would be transformed into an investment vehicle. The Board of Tungsten has spent considerable time reviewing these suggestions, including the most recent proposal, and found them to date to be universally without merit for shareholders.

The Board believes it has made significant progress in addressing the challenges facing Tungsten and now believes that the Group strategy as set out at Tungsten's Capital Markets Day on 9 February 2016 remains the best and most certain path to maximise the creation of shareholder value.

The Board's priority is to oversee the effective execution of this strategy under the leadership of Richard M. Hurwitz, Chief Executive Officer, and his executive management team; it believes that distractions from that risk destroying value.
